You shall not in your funeral speech blame us 270
But speak all good you can devise of Caesar
And say you do ’t by our permission,
Else shall you not have any hand at all
About his funeral. And you shall speak
In the same pulpit whereto I am going, 275
After my speech is ended.
113 Julius Caesar ACT 3. SC. 1
ANTONY Be it so.
I do desire no more.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: The Capitol - Caesar is assassinated

text:
Prepare the body, then, and follow us.
All but Antony exit.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: The Capitol - Caesar is assassinated

text:
O pardon me, thou bleeding piece of earth, 280
That I am meek and gentle with these butchers.
Thou art the ruins of the noblest man
That ever livèd in the tide of times.
Woe to the hand that shed this costly blood!
Over thy wounds now do I prophesy 285
(Which like dumb mouths do ope their ruby lips
To beg the voice and utterance of my tongue)
A curse shall light upon the limbs of men;
Domestic fury and fierce civil strife
Shall cumber all the parts of Italy; 290
Blood and destruction shall be so in use
And dreadful objects so familiar
That mothers shall but smile when they behold
Their infants quartered with the hands of war,
All pity choked with custom of fell deeds; 295
And Caesar’s spirit, ranging for revenge,
With Ate by his side come hot from hell,
Shall in these confines with a monarch’s voice
Cry “Havoc!” and let slip the dogs of war,
That this foul deed shall smell above the earth 300
With carrion men groaning for burial.
Enter Octavius’ Servant.
You serve Octavius Caesar, do you not?
SERVANT I do, Mark Antony.
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: The Capitol - Caesar is assassinated

text: Caesar did write for him to come to Rome.
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: The Capitol - Caesar is assassinated

text:
He did receive his letters and is coming, 305
115 Julius Caesar ACT 3. SC. 2
And bid me say to you by word of mouth—
O Caesar!
speaker: SERVANT
scene_description: The Capitol - Caesar is assassinated

text:
Thy heart is big. Get thee apart and weep.
Passion, I see, is catching, for mine eyes,
Seeing those beads of sorrow stand in thine, 310
Began to water. Is thy master coming?
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: The Capitol - Caesar is assassinated

text: He lies tonight within seven leagues of Rome.
speaker: SERVANT
scene_description: The Capitol - Caesar is assassinated

text:
Post back with speed and tell him what hath
chanced.
Here is a mourning Rome, a dangerous Rome, 315
No Rome of safety for Octavius yet.
Hie hence and tell him so.—Yet stay awhile;
Thou shalt not back till I have borne this corpse
Into the marketplace. There shall I try,
In my oration, how the people take 320
The cruel issue of these bloody men,
According to the which thou shalt discourse
To young Octavius of the state of things.
Lend me your hand.
They exit with Caesar’s body.
Enter Brutus and Cassius with the Plebeians.
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text: We will be satisfied! Let us be satisfied!
speaker: PLEBEIANS
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
Then follow me and give me audience, friends.—
Cassius, go you into the other street
And part the numbers.—
Those that will hear me speak, let ’em stay here; 5
Those that will follow Cassius, go with him;
117 Julius Caesar ACT 3. SC. 2
And public reasons shall be renderèd
Of Caesar’s death.
FIRST PLEBEIAN I will hear Brutus speak.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
I will hear Cassius, and compare their reasons 10
When severally we hear them renderèd.
Cassius exits with some of the Plebeians.
Brutus goes into the pulpit.
speaker: SECOND PLEBEIAN
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
The noble Brutus is ascended. Silence.
BRUTUS Be patient till the last.
Romans, countrymen, and lovers, hear me for my
cause, and be silent that you may hear. Believe me 15
for mine honor, and have respect to mine honor
that you may believe. Censure me in your wisdom,
and awake your senses that you may the better
judge. If there be any in this assembly, any dear
friend of Caesar’s, to him I say that Brutus’ love 20
to Caesar was no less than his. If then that friend
demand why Brutus rose against Caesar, this is my
answer: not that I loved Caesar less, but that I loved
Rome more. Had you rather Caesar were living, and
die all slaves, than that Caesar were dead, to live all 25
freemen? As Caesar loved me, I weep for him. As he
was fortunate, I rejoice at it. As he was valiant, I
honor him. But, as he was ambitious, I slew him.
There is tears for his love, joy for his fortune, honor
for his valor, and death for his ambition. Who is 30
here so base that would be a bondman? If any,
speak, for him have I offended. Who is here so rude
that would not be a Roman? If any, speak, for him
have I offended. Who is here so vile that will not
love his country? If any, speak, for him have I 35
offended. I pause for a reply.
PLEBEIANS None, Brutus, none.
BRUTUS Then none have I offended. I have done no
119 Julius Caesar ACT 3. SC. 2
more to Caesar than you shall do to Brutus. The
question of his death is enrolled in the Capitol, his 40
glory not extenuated wherein he was worthy, nor
his offenses enforced for which he suffered death.
Enter Mark Antony and others with Caesar’s body.
Here comes his body, mourned by Mark Antony,
who, though he had no hand in his death, shall
receive the benefit of his dying—a place in the 45
commonwealth—as which of you shall not? With
this I depart: that, as I slew my best lover for the
good of Rome, I have the same dagger for myself
when it shall please my country to need my death.
PLEBEIANS Live, Brutus, live, live! 50
speaker: THIRD PLEBEIAN
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text: Bring him with triumph home unto his house.
speaker: FIRST PLEBEIAN
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text: Give him a statue with his ancestors.
speaker: SECOND PLEBEIAN
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
Let him be Caesar.
FOURTH PLEBEIAN Caesar’s better parts
Shall be crowned in Brutus. 55
speaker: THIRD PLEBEIAN
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
We’ll bring him to his house with shouts and
clamors.
speaker: FIRST PLEBEIAN
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
My countrymen—
SECOND PLEBEIAN Peace, silence! Brutus speaks.
FIRST PLEBEIAN Peace, ho! 60
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
Good countrymen, let me depart alone,
And, for my sake, stay here with Antony.
Do grace to Caesar’s corpse, and grace his speech
Tending to Caesar’s glories, which Mark Antony
(By our permission) is allowed to make. 65
121 Julius Caesar ACT 3. SC. 2
I do entreat you, not a man depart,
Save I alone, till Antony have spoke.
He descends and exits.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text: Stay, ho, and let us hear Mark Antony!
speaker: FIRST PLEBEIAN
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text: Let him go up into the public chair.
speaker: THIRD PLEBEIAN
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text: We’ll hear him.—Noble Antony, go up. 70
speaker: PLEBEIANS
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
For Brutus’ sake, I am beholding to you.
He goes into the pulpit.
FOURTH PLEBEIAN What does he say of Brutus?
THIRD PLEBEIAN He says for Brutus’ sake
He finds himself beholding to us all.
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text: ’Twere best he speak no harm of Brutus here. 75
speaker: FOURTH PLEBEIAN
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
This Caesar was a tyrant.
THIRD PLEBEIAN Nay, that’s certain.
We are blest that Rome is rid of him.
speaker: FIRST PLEBEIAN
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text: Peace, let us hear what Antony can say.
speaker: SECOND PLEBEIAN
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
You gentle Romans— 80
PLEBEIANS Peace, ho! Let us hear him.
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
Friends, Romans, countrymen, lend me your ears.
I come to bury Caesar, not to praise him.
The evil that men do lives after them;
The good is oft interrèd with their bones. 85
So let it be with Caesar. The noble Brutus
Hath told you Caesar was ambitious.
If it were so, it was a grievous fault,
And grievously hath Caesar answered it.
Here, under leave of Brutus and the rest 90
(For Brutus is an honorable man;
123 Julius Caesar ACT 3. SC. 2
So are they all, all honorable men),
Come I to speak in Caesar’s funeral.
He was my friend, faithful and just to me,
But Brutus says he was ambitious, 95
And Brutus is an honorable man.
He hath brought many captives home to Rome,
Whose ransoms did the general coffers fill.
Did this in Caesar seem ambitious?
When that the poor have cried, Caesar hath wept; 100
Ambition should be made of sterner stuff.
Yet Brutus says he was ambitious,
And Brutus is an honorable man.
You all did see that on the Lupercal
I thrice presented him a kingly crown, 105
Which he did thrice refuse. Was this ambition?
Yet Brutus says he was ambitious,
And sure he is an honorable man.
I speak not to disprove what Brutus spoke,
But here I am to speak what I do know. 110
You all did love him once, not without cause.
What cause withholds you, then, to mourn for
him?—
O judgment, thou art fled to brutish beasts,
And men have lost their reason!—Bear with me; 115
My heart is in the coffin there with Caesar,
And I must pause till it come back to me. He weeps.
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text: Methinks there is much reason in his sayings.
speaker: FIRST PLEBEIAN
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
If thou consider rightly of the matter,
Caesar has had great wrong. 120
THIRD PLEBEIAN Has he, masters?
I fear there will a worse come in his place.
speaker: SECOND PLEBEIAN
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
Marked you his words? He would not take the
crown;
Therefore ’tis certain he was not ambitious. 125
125 Julius Caesar ACT 3. SC. 2
speaker: FOURTH PLEBEIAN
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text: If it be found so, some will dear abide it.
speaker: FIRST PLEBEIAN
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text: Poor soul, his eyes are red as fire with weeping.
speaker: SECOND PLEBEIAN
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text: There’s not a nobler man in Rome than Antony.
speaker: THIRD PLEBEIAN
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text: Now mark him. He begins again to speak.
speaker: FOURTH PLEBEIAN
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
But yesterday the word of Caesar might 130
Have stood against the world. Now lies he there,
And none so poor to do him reverence.
O masters, if I were disposed to stir
Your hearts and minds to mutiny and rage,
I should do Brutus wrong and Cassius wrong, 135
Who, you all know, are honorable men.
I will not do them wrong. I rather choose
To wrong the dead, to wrong myself and you,
Than I will wrong such honorable men.
But here’s a parchment with the seal of Caesar. 140
I found it in his closet. ’Tis his will.
Let but the commons hear this testament,
Which, pardon me, I do not mean to read,
And they would go and kiss dead Caesar’s wounds
And dip their napkins in his sacred blood— 145
Yea, beg a hair of him for memory
And, dying, mention it within their wills,
Bequeathing it as a rich legacy
Unto their issue.
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text: We’ll hear the will. Read it, Mark Antony. 150
speaker: FOURTH PLEBEIAN
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text: The will, the will! We will hear Caesar’s will.
speaker: PLEBEIANS
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
Have patience, gentle friends. I must not read it.
127 Julius Caesar ACT 3. SC. 2
It is not meet you know how Caesar loved you.
You are not wood, you are not stones, but men.
And, being men, hearing the will of Caesar, 155
It will inflame you; it will make you mad.
’Tis good you know not that you are his heirs,
For if you should, O, what would come of it?
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text: Read the will! We’ll hear it, Antony.
speaker: FOURTH PLEBEIAN
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text: You shall read us the will, Caesar’s will. 160
speaker: PLEBEIANS
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
Will you be patient? Will you stay awhile?
I have o’ershot myself to tell you of it.
I fear I wrong the honorable men
Whose daggers have stabbed Caesar. I do fear it.
FOURTH PLEBEIAN They were traitors. Honorable men? 165
PLEBEIANS The will! The testament!
SECOND PLEBEIAN They were villains, murderers. The
will! Read the will.
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
You will compel me, then, to read the will?
Then make a ring about the corpse of Caesar, 170
And let me show you him that made the will.
Shall I descend? And will you give me leave?
PLEBEIANS Come down.
SECOND PLEBEIAN Descend.
THIRD PLEBEIAN You shall have leave. 175
Antony descends.
FOURTH PLEBEIAN A ring; stand round.
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text: Stand from the hearse. Stand from the body.
speaker: FIRST PLEBEIAN
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text: Room for Antony, most noble Antony.
speaker: SECOND PLEBEIAN
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
Nay, press not so upon me. Stand far off.
129 Julius Caesar ACT 3. SC. 2
PLEBEIANS Stand back! Room! Bear back! 180
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
If you have tears, prepare to shed them now.
You all do know this mantle. I remember
The first time ever Caesar put it on.
’Twas on a summer’s evening in his tent,
That day he overcame the Nervii. 185
Look, in this place ran Cassius’ dagger through.
See what a rent the envious Casca made.
Through this the well-belovèd Brutus stabbed,
And, as he plucked his cursèd steel away,
Mark how the blood of Caesar followed it, 190
As rushing out of doors to be resolved
If Brutus so unkindly knocked or no;
For Brutus, as you know, was Caesar’s angel.
Judge, O you gods, how dearly Caesar loved him!
This was the most unkindest cut of all. 195
For when the noble Caesar saw him stab,
Ingratitude, more strong than traitors’ arms,
Quite vanquished him. Then burst his mighty heart,
And, in his mantle muffling up his face,
Even at the base of Pompey’s statue 200
(Which all the while ran blood) great Caesar fell.
O, what a fall was there, my countrymen!
Then I and you and all of us fell down,
Whilst bloody treason flourished over us.
O, now you weep, and I perceive you feel 205
The dint of pity. These are gracious drops.
Kind souls, what, weep you when you but behold
Our Caesar’s vesture wounded? Look you here,
Antony lifts Caesar’s cloak.
Here is himself, marred as you see with traitors.
FIRST PLEBEIAN O piteous spectacle! 210
SECOND PLEBEIAN O noble Caesar!
THIRD PLEBEIAN O woeful day!
131 Julius Caesar ACT 3. SC. 2
FOURTH PLEBEIAN O traitors, villains!
FIRST PLEBEIAN O most bloody sight!
SECOND PLEBEIAN We will be revenged. 215
PLEBEIANS Revenge! About! Seek! Burn! Fire! Kill!
Slay! Let not a traitor live!
ANTONY Stay, countrymen.
FIRST PLEBEIAN Peace there! Hear the noble Antony.
SECOND PLEBEIAN We’ll hear him, we’ll follow him, 220
we’ll die with him.
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
Good friends, sweet friends, let me not stir you up
To such a sudden flood of mutiny.
They that have done this deed are honorable.
What private griefs they have, alas, I know not, 225
That made them do it. They are wise and honorable
And will no doubt with reasons answer you.
I come not, friends, to steal away your hearts.
I am no orator, as Brutus is,
But, as you know me all, a plain blunt man 230
That love my friend, and that they know full well
That gave me public leave to speak of him.
For I have neither wit, nor words, nor worth,
Action, nor utterance, nor the power of speech
To stir men’s blood. I only speak right on. 235
I tell you that which you yourselves do know,
Show you sweet Caesar’s wounds, poor poor dumb
mouths,
And bid them speak for me. But were I Brutus,
And Brutus Antony, there were an Antony 240
Would ruffle up your spirits and put a tongue
In every wound of Caesar that should move
The stones of Rome to rise and mutiny.
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
We’ll mutiny.
FIRST PLEBEIAN We’ll burn the house of Brutus. 245
133 Julius Caesar ACT 3. SC. 2
speaker: PLEBEIANS
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text: Away then. Come, seek the conspirators.
speaker: THIRD PLEBEIAN
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text: Yet hear me, countrymen; yet hear me speak.
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text: Peace, ho! Hear Antony, most noble Antony!
speaker: PLEBEIANS
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
Why, friends, you go to do you know not what.
Wherein hath Caesar thus deserved your loves? 250
Alas, you know not. I must tell you then.
You have forgot the will I told you of.
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text: Most true. The will! Let’s stay and hear the will.
speaker: PLEBEIANS
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
Here is the will, and under Caesar’s seal:
To every Roman citizen he gives, 255
To every several man, seventy-five drachmas.
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
Most noble Caesar! We’ll revenge his death.
THIRD PLEBEIAN O royal Caesar!
ANTONY Hear me with patience.
PLEBEIANS Peace, ho! 260
speaker: SECOND PLEBEIAN
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
Moreover, he hath left you all his walks,
His private arbors, and new-planted orchards,
On this side Tiber. He hath left them you,
And to your heirs forever—common pleasures
To walk abroad and recreate yourselves. 265
Here was a Caesar! When comes such another?
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
Never, never!—Come, away, away!
We’ll burn his body in the holy place
And with the brands fire the traitors’ houses.
Take up the body. 270
SECOND PLEBEIAN Go fetch fire.
THIRD PLEBEIAN Pluck down benches.
135 Julius Caesar ACT 3. SC. 3
FOURTH PLEBEIAN Pluck down forms, windows,
anything.
Plebeians exit with Caesar’s body.
speaker: FIRST PLEBEIAN
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
Now let it work. Mischief, thou art afoot; 275
Take thou what course thou wilt.
Enter Servant.
How now, fellow?
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
Sir, Octavius is already come to Rome.
ANTONY Where is he?
speaker: SERVANT
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text: He and Lepidus are at Caesar’s house. 280
speaker: SERVANT
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
And thither will I straight to visit him.
He comes upon a wish. Fortune is merry
And in this mood will give us anything.
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
I heard him say Brutus and Cassius
Are rid like madmen through the gates of Rome. 285
speaker: SERVANT
scene_description: The Forum - Brutus and Antony deliver funeral orations

text:
Belike they had some notice of the people
How I had moved them. Bring me to Octavius.
They exit.
Enter Cinna the poet and after him the Plebeians.
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: A street - Mob violence begins

text:
I dreamt tonight that I did feast with Caesar,
And things unluckily charge my fantasy.
I have no will to wander forth of doors,
Yet something leads me forth.
FIRST PLEBEIAN What is your name? 5
137 Julius Caesar ACT 3. SC. 3
SECOND PLEBEIAN Whither are you going?
THIRD PLEBEIAN Where do you dwell?
FOURTH PLEBEIAN Are you a married man or a
bachelor?
SECOND PLEBEIAN Answer every man directly. 10
FIRST PLEBEIAN Ay, and briefly.
FOURTH PLEBEIAN Ay, and wisely.
THIRD PLEBEIAN Ay, and truly, you were best.
CINNA What is my name? Whither am I going? Where
do I dwell? Am I a married man or a bachelor? 15
Then to answer every man directly and briefly,
wisely and truly: wisely I say, I am a bachelor.
SECOND PLEBEIAN That’s as much as to say they are
fools that marry. You’ll bear me a bang for that, I
fear. Proceed directly. 20
CINNA Directly, I am going to Caesar’s funeral.
FIRST PLEBEIAN As a friend or an enemy?
CINNA As a friend.
SECOND PLEBEIAN That matter is answered directly.
FOURTH PLEBEIAN For your dwelling—briefly. 25
CINNA Briefly, I dwell by the Capitol.
THIRD PLEBEIAN Your name, sir, truly.
CINNA Truly, my name is Cinna.
FIRST PLEBEIAN Tear him to pieces! He’s a conspirator.
CINNA I am Cinna the poet, I am Cinna the poet! 30
FOURTH PLEBEIAN Tear him for his bad verses, tear him
for his bad verses!
CINNA I am not Cinna the conspirator.
FOURTH PLEBEIAN It is no matter. His name’s Cinna.
Pluck but his name out of his heart, and turn him 35
going.
THIRD PLEBEIAN Tear him, tear him! Come, brands, ho,
firebrands! To Brutus’, to Cassius’, burn all! Some
to Decius’ house, and some to Casca’s, some to
Ligarius’. Away, go! 40
All the Plebeians exit, carrying off Cinna.
Enter Antony, Octavius, and Lepidus.
speaker: CINNA
scene_description: House of Antony - The triumvirate plans revenge

text:
These many, then, shall die; their names are
pricked.
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: House of Antony - The triumvirate plans revenge

text: Your brother too must die. Consent you, Lepidus?
speaker: OCTAVIUS
scene_description: House of Antony - The triumvirate plans revenge

text:
I do consent.
OCTAVIUS Prick him down, Antony. 5
speaker: LEPIDUS
scene_description: House of Antony - The triumvirate plans revenge

text:
Upon condition Publius shall not live,
Who is your sister’s son, Mark Antony.
speaker: LEPIDUS
scene_description: House of Antony - The triumvirate plans revenge

text:
He shall not live; look, with a spot I damn him.
But, Lepidus, go you to Caesar’s house;
Fetch the will hither, and we shall determine 10
How to cut off some charge in legacies.
LEPIDUS What, shall I find you here?
OCTAVIUS Or here, or at the Capitol. Lepidus exits.
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: House of Antony - The triumvirate plans revenge

text:
This is a slight, unmeritable man,
Meet to be sent on errands. Is it fit, 15
The threefold world divided, he should stand
One of the three to share it?
141
143 Julius Caesar ACT 4. SC. 1
OCTAVIUS So you thought him
And took his voice who should be pricked to die
In our black sentence and proscription. 20
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: House of Antony - The triumvirate plans revenge

text:
Octavius, I have seen more days than you,
And, though we lay these honors on this man
To ease ourselves of diverse sland’rous loads,
He shall but bear them as the ass bears gold,
To groan and sweat under the business, 25
Either led or driven, as we point the way;
And having brought our treasure where we will,
Then take we down his load and turn him off
(Like to the empty ass) to shake his ears
And graze in commons. 30
OCTAVIUS You may do your will,
But he’s a tried and valiant soldier.
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: House of Antony - The triumvirate plans revenge

text:
So is my horse, Octavius, and for that
I do appoint him store of provender.
It is a creature that I teach to fight, 35
To wind, to stop, to run directly on,
His corporal motion governed by my spirit;
And, in some taste, is Lepidus but so.
He must be taught and trained and bid go forth—
A barren-spirited fellow, one that feeds 40
On objects, arts, and imitations
Which, out of use and staled by other men,
Begin his fashion. Do not talk of him
But as a property. And now, Octavius,
Listen great things. Brutus and Cassius 45
Are levying powers. We must straight make head.
Therefore let our alliance be combined,
Our best friends made, our means stretched;
And let us presently go sit in council
How covert matters may be best disclosed 50
And open perils surest answerèd.
145 Julius Caesar ACT 4. SC. 2
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: House of Antony - The triumvirate plans revenge

text:
Let us do so, for we are at the stake
And bayed about with many enemies,
And some that smile have in their hearts, I fear,
Millions of mischiefs. 55
They exit.
Drum. Enter Brutus, Lucilius, Lucius, and the Army.
Titinius and Pindarus meet them.
BRUTUS Stand ho!
LUCILIUS Give the word, ho, and stand!
speaker: OCTAVIUS
scene_description: Brutus's camp - Argument

text: What now, Lucilius, is Cassius near?
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's camp - Argument

text:
He is at hand, and Pindarus is come
To do you salutation from his master. 5
speaker: LUCILIUS
scene_description: Brutus's camp - Argument

text:
He greets me well.—Your master, Pindarus,
In his own change or by ill officers,
Hath given me some worthy cause to wish
Things done undone, but if he be at hand
I shall be satisfied. 10
PINDARUS I do not doubt
But that my noble master will appear
Such as he is, full of regard and honor.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's camp - Argument

text:
He is not doubted. Brutus and Lucilius walk aside.
A word, Lucilius, 15
How he received you. Let me be resolved.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's camp - Argument

text:
With courtesy and with respect enough,
But not with such familiar instances
Nor with such free and friendly conference
As he hath used of old. 20
147 Julius Caesar ACT 4. SC. 2
BRUTUS Thou hast described
A hot friend cooling. Ever note, Lucilius,
When love begins to sicken and decay
It useth an enforcèd ceremony.
There are no tricks in plain and simple faith; 25
But hollow men, like horses hot at hand,
Make gallant show and promise of their mettle,
Low march within.
But when they should endure the bloody spur,
They fall their crests and, like deceitful jades,
Sink in the trial. Comes his army on? 30
speaker: LUCILIUS
scene_description: Brutus's camp - Argument

text:
They mean this night in Sardis to be quartered.
The greater part, the horse in general,
Are come with Cassius.
Enter Cassius and his powers.
BRUTUS Hark, he is arrived.
March gently on to meet him. 35
CASSIUS Stand ho!
BRUTUS Stand ho! Speak the word along.
FIRST SOLDIER Stand!
SECOND SOLDIER Stand!
THIRD SOLDIER Stand! 40
speaker: LUCILIUS
scene_description: Brutus's camp - Argument

text: Most noble brother, you have done me wrong.
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's camp - Argument

text:
Judge me, you gods! Wrong I mine enemies?
And if not so, how should I wrong a brother?
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's camp - Argument

text:
Brutus, this sober form of yours hides wrongs,
And when you do them— 45
BRUTUS Cassius, be content.
Speak your griefs softly. I do know you well.
Before the eyes of both our armies here
(Which should perceive nothing but love from us),
149 Julius Caesar ACT 4. SC. 3
Let us not wrangle. Bid them move away. 50
Then in my tent, Cassius, enlarge your griefs,
And I will give you audience.
CASSIUS Pindarus,
Bid our commanders lead their charges off
A little from this ground. 55
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's camp - Argument

text:
Lucius, do you the like, and let no man
Come to our tent till we have done our conference.
Let Lucilius and Titinius guard our door.
All but Brutus and Cassius exit.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
That you have wronged me doth appear in this:
You have condemned and noted Lucius Pella
For taking bribes here of the Sardians,
Wherein my letters, praying on his side
Because I knew the man, was slighted off. 5
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text: You wronged yourself to write in such a case.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
In such a time as this it is not meet
That every nice offense should bear his comment.
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Let me tell you, Cassius, you yourself
Are much condemned to have an itching palm, 10
To sell and mart your offices for gold
To undeservers.
CASSIUS I an itching palm?
You know that you are Brutus that speaks this,
Or, by the gods, this speech were else your last. 15
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
The name of Cassius honors this corruption,
And chastisement doth therefore hide his head.
151 Julius Caesar ACT 4. SC. 3
CASSIUS Chastisement?
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Remember March; the ides of March remember.
Did not great Julius bleed for justice’ sake? 20
What villain touched his body that did stab
And not for justice? What, shall one of us
That struck the foremost man of all this world
But for supporting robbers, shall we now
Contaminate our fingers with base bribes 25
And sell the mighty space of our large honors
For so much trash as may be graspèd thus?
I had rather be a dog and bay the moon
Than such a Roman.
CASSIUS Brutus, bait not me. 30
I’ll not endure it. You forget yourself
To hedge me in. I am a soldier, I,
Older in practice, abler than yourself
To make conditions.
BRUTUS Go to! You are not, Cassius. 35
CASSIUS I am.
BRUTUS I say you are not.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Urge me no more. I shall forget myself.
Have mind upon your health. Tempt me no farther.
BRUTUS Away, slight man! 40
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Is ’t possible?
BRUTUS Hear me, for I will speak.
Must I give way and room to your rash choler?
Shall I be frighted when a madman stares?
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text: O you gods, you gods, must I endure all this? 45
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
All this? Ay, more. Fret till your proud heart break.
Go show your slaves how choleric you are
And make your bondmen tremble. Must I budge?
153 Julius Caesar ACT 4. SC. 3
Must I observe you? Must I stand and crouch
Under your testy humor? By the gods, 50
You shall digest the venom of your spleen
Though it do split you. For, from this day forth,
I’ll use you for my mirth, yea, for my laughter,
When you are waspish.
CASSIUS Is it come to this? 55
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
You say you are a better soldier.
Let it appear so, make your vaunting true,
And it shall please me well. For mine own part,
I shall be glad to learn of noble men.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
You wrong me every way, you wrong me, Brutus. 60
I said an elder soldier, not a better.
Did I say “better”?
BRUTUS If you did, I care not.
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
When Caesar lived he durst not thus have moved
me. 65
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Peace, peace! You durst not so have tempted him.
CASSIUS I durst not?
BRUTUS No.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
What? Durst not tempt him?
BRUTUS For your life you durst 70
not.
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Do not presume too much upon my love.
I may do that I shall be sorry for.
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
You have done that you should be sorry for.
There is no terror, Cassius, in your threats, 75
For I am armed so strong in honesty
That they pass by me as the idle wind,
155 Julius Caesar ACT 4. SC. 3
Which I respect not. I did send to you
For certain sums of gold, which you denied me,
For I can raise no money by vile means. 80
By heaven, I had rather coin my heart
And drop my blood for drachmas than to wring
From the hard hands of peasants their vile trash
By any indirection. I did send
To you for gold to pay my legions, 85
Which you denied me. Was that done like Cassius?
Should I have answered Caius Cassius so?
When Marcus Brutus grows so covetous
To lock such rascal counters from his friends,
Be ready, gods, with all your thunderbolts; 90
Dash him to pieces!
CASSIUS I denied you not.
BRUTUS You did.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
I did not. He was but a fool that brought
My answer back. Brutus hath rived my heart. 95
A friend should bear his friend’s infirmities,
But Brutus makes mine greater than they are.
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text: I do not, till you practice them on me.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
You love me not.
BRUTUS I do not like your faults. 100
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text: A friendly eye could never see such faults.
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
A flatterer’s would not, though they do appear
As huge as high Olympus.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Come, Antony, and young Octavius, come!
Revenge yourselves alone on Cassius, 105
For Cassius is aweary of the world—
Hated by one he loves, braved by his brother,
157 Julius Caesar ACT 4. SC. 3
Checked like a bondman, all his faults observed,
Set in a notebook, learned and conned by rote
To cast into my teeth. O, I could weep 110
My spirit from mine eyes! There is my dagger,
Offering his dagger to Brutus.
And here my naked breast; within, a heart
Dearer than Pluto’s mine, richer than gold.
If that thou be’st a Roman, take it forth.
I that denied thee gold will give my heart. 115
Strike as thou didst at Caesar, for I know
When thou didst hate him worst, thou lovedst him
better
Than ever thou lovedst Cassius.
BRUTUS Sheathe your 120
dagger.
Be angry when you will, it shall have scope.
Do what you will, dishonor shall be humor.
O Cassius, you are yokèd with a lamb
That carries anger as the flint bears fire, 125
Who, much enforcèd, shows a hasty spark
And straight is cold again.
CASSIUS Hath Cassius lived
To be but mirth and laughter to his Brutus
When grief and blood ill-tempered vexeth him? 130
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text: When I spoke that, I was ill-tempered too.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text: Do you confess so much? Give me your hand.
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
And my heart too. They clasp hands.
CASSIUS O Brutus!
BRUTUS What’s the matter? 135
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Have not you love enough to bear with me
When that rash humor which my mother gave me
Makes me forgetful?
159 Julius Caesar ACT 4. SC. 3
BRUTUS Yes, Cassius, and from
henceforth 140
When you are over-earnest with your Brutus,
He’ll think your mother chides, and leave you so.
Enter a Poet followed by Lucilius, Titinius, and Lucius.
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Let me go in to see the Generals.
There is some grudge between ’em; ’tis not meet
They be alone. 145
LUCILIUS You shall not come to them.
POET Nothing but death shall stay me.
CASSIUS How now, what’s the matter?
speaker: POET
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
For shame, you generals, what do you mean?
Love and be friends as two such men should be, 150
For I have seen more years, I’m sure, than ye.
speaker: POET
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text: Ha, ha, how vilely doth this cynic rhyme!
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text: Get you hence, sirrah! Saucy fellow, hence!
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text: Bear with him, Brutus. ’Tis his fashion.
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
I’ll know his humor when he knows his time. 155
What should the wars do with these jigging fools?—
Companion, hence!
CASSIUS Away, away, be gone! Poet exits.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Lucilius and Titinius, bid the commanders
Prepare to lodge their companies tonight. 160
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
And come yourselves, and bring Messala with you
Immediately to us. Lucilius and Titinius exit.
BRUTUS Lucius, a bowl of wine. Lucius exits.
161 Julius Caesar ACT 4. SC. 3
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text: I did not think you could have been so angry.
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text: O Cassius, I am sick of many griefs. 165
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Of your philosophy you make no use
If you give place to accidental evils.
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
No man bears sorrow better. Portia is dead.
CASSIUS Ha? Portia?
BRUTUS She is dead. 170
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
How ’scaped I killing when I crossed you so?
O insupportable and touching loss!
Upon what sickness?
BRUTUS Impatient of my absence,
And grief that young Octavius with Mark Antony 175
Have made themselves so strong—for with her
death
That tidings came—with this she fell distract
And, her attendants absent, swallowed fire.
CASSIUS And died so? 180
BRUTUS Even so.
CASSIUS O you immortal gods!
Enter Lucius with wine and tapers.
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Speak no more of her.—Give me a bowl of wine.—
In this I bury all unkindness, Cassius. He drinks.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
My heart is thirsty for that noble pledge.— 185
Fill, Lucius, till the wine o’erswell the cup;
I cannot drink too much of Brutus’ love. He drinks.
Lucius exits.
Enter Titinius and Messala.
163 Julius Caesar ACT 4. SC. 3
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Come in, Titinius. Welcome, good Messala.
Now sit we close about this taper here,
And call in question our necessities. They sit. 190
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Portia, art thou gone?
BRUTUS No more, I pray you.—
Messala, I have here receivèd letters
That young Octavius and Mark Antony
Come down upon us with a mighty power, 195
Bending their expedition toward Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Myself have letters of the selfsame tenor.
BRUTUS With what addition?
speaker: MESSALA
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
That by proscription and bills of outlawry,
Octavius, Antony, and Lepidus 200
Have put to death an hundred senators.
speaker: MESSALA
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Therein our letters do not well agree.
Mine speak of seventy senators that died
By their proscriptions, Cicero being one.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Cicero one? 205
MESSALA Cicero is dead,
And by that order of proscription.
Had you your letters from your wife, my lord?
BRUTUS No, Messala.
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Nor nothing in your letters writ of her? 210
BRUTUS Nothing, Messala.
MESSALA That methinks is strange.
speaker: MESSALA
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Why ask you? Hear you aught of her in yours?
MESSALA No, my lord.
165 Julius Caesar ACT 4. SC. 3
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text: Now, as you are a Roman, tell me true. 215
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Then like a Roman bear the truth I tell,
For certain she is dead, and by strange manner.
speaker: MESSALA
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Why, farewell, Portia. We must die, Messala.
With meditating that she must die once,
I have the patience to endure it now. 220
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text: Even so great men great losses should endure.
speaker: MESSALA
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
I have as much of this in art as you,
But yet my nature could not bear it so.
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Well, to our work alive. What do you think
Of marching to Philippi presently? 225
CASSIUS I do not think it good.
BRUTUS Your reason?
CASSIUS This it is:
’Tis better that the enemy seek us;
So shall he waste his means, weary his soldiers, 230
Doing himself offense, whilst we, lying still,
Are full of rest, defense, and nimbleness.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Good reasons must of force give place to better.
The people ’twixt Philippi and this ground
Do stand but in a forced affection, 235
For they have grudged us contribution.
The enemy, marching along by them,
By them shall make a fuller number up,
Come on refreshed, new-added, and encouraged,
From which advantage shall we cut him off 240
If at Philippi we do face him there,
These people at our back.
CASSIUS Hear me, good brother—
167 Julius Caesar ACT 4. SC. 3
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Under your pardon. You must note besides
That we have tried the utmost of our friends, 245
Our legions are brim full, our cause is ripe.
The enemy increaseth every day;
We, at the height, are ready to decline.
There is a tide in the affairs of men
Which, taken at the flood, leads on to fortune; 250
Omitted, all the voyage of their life
Is bound in shallows and in miseries.
On such a full sea are we now afloat,
And we must take the current when it serves
Or lose our ventures. 255
CASSIUS Then, with your will, go on;
We’ll along ourselves and meet them at Philippi.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
The deep of night is crept upon our talk,
And nature must obey necessity,
Which we will niggard with a little rest. 260
There is no more to say.
CASSIUS No more. Good night.
They stand.
Early tomorrow will we rise and hence.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Lucius.
Enter Lucius.
My gown. Lucius exits. 265
Farewell, good Messala.—
Good night, Titinius.—Noble, noble Cassius,
Good night and good repose.
CASSIUS O my dear brother,
This was an ill beginning of the night. 270
Never come such division ’tween our souls!
Let it not, Brutus.
Enter Lucius with the gown.
169 Julius Caesar ACT 4. SC. 3
BRUTUS Everything is well.
CASSIUS Good night, my lord.
BRUTUS Good night, good brother. 275
TITINIUS/MESSALA
Good night, Lord Brutus.
BRUTUS Farewell, everyone.
All but Brutus and Lucius exit.
Give me the gown. Where is thy instrument?
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Here in the tent.
BRUTUS What, thou speak’st drowsily? 280
Poor knave, I blame thee not; thou art o’erwatched.
Call Claudius and some other of my men;
I’ll have them sleep on cushions in my tent.
LUCIUS Varro and Claudius.
Enter Varro and Claudius.
VARRO Calls my lord? 285
speaker: LUCIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
I pray you, sirs, lie in my tent and sleep.
It may be I shall raise you by and by
On business to my brother Cassius.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
So please you, we will stand and watch your
pleasure. 290
speaker: VARRO
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
I will not have it so. Lie down, good sirs.
It may be I shall otherwise bethink me.
They lie down.
Look, Lucius, here’s the book I sought for so.
I put it in the pocket of my gown.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text: I was sure your Lordship did not give it me. 295
speaker: LUCIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Bear with me, good boy, I am much forgetful.
171 Julius Caesar ACT 4. SC. 3
Canst thou hold up thy heavy eyes awhile
And touch thy instrument a strain or two?
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Ay, my lord, an ’t please you.
BRUTUS It does, my boy. 300
I trouble thee too much, but thou art willing.
LUCIUS It is my duty, sir.
speaker: LUCIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
I should not urge thy duty past thy might.
I know young bloods look for a time of rest.
LUCIUS I have slept, my lord, already. 305
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
It was well done, and thou shalt sleep again.
I will not hold thee long. If I do live,
I will be good to thee.
Music and a song. Lucius then falls asleep.
This is a sleepy tune. O murd’rous slumber,
Layest thou thy leaden mace upon my boy, 310
That plays thee music?—Gentle knave, good night.
I will not do thee so much wrong to wake thee.
If thou dost nod, thou break’st thy instrument.
I’ll take it from thee and, good boy, good night.
He moves the instrument.
Let me see, let me see; is not the leaf turned down 315
Where I left reading? Here it is, I think.
How ill this taper burns.
Enter the Ghost of Caesar.
Ha, who comes here?—
I think it is the weakness of mine eyes
That shapes this monstrous apparition. 320
It comes upon me.—Art thou any thing?
Art thou some god, some angel, or some devil,
That mak’st my blood cold and my hair to stare?
Speak to me what thou art.
173 Julius Caesar ACT 4. SC. 3
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Thy evil spirit, Brutus. 325
BRUTUS Why com’st thou?
speaker: GHOST
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
To tell thee thou shalt see me at Philippi.
BRUTUS Well, then I shall see thee again?
GHOST Ay, at Philippi.
speaker: GHOST
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Why, I will see thee at Philippi, then. Ghost exits. 330
Now I have taken heart, thou vanishest.
Ill spirit, I would hold more talk with thee.—
Boy, Lucius!—Varro, Claudius, sirs, awake!
Claudius!
LUCIUS The strings, my lord, are false. 335
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
He thinks he still is at his instrument.
Lucius, awake!
LUCIUS My lord?
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text: Didst thou dream, Lucius, that thou so criedst out?
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text: My lord, I do not know that I did cry. 340
speaker: LUCIUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Yes, that thou didst. Didst thou see anything?
LUCIUS Nothing, my lord.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Sleep again, Lucius.—Sirrah Claudius!
To Varro. Fellow thou, awake! They rise up.
VARRO My lord? 345
CLAUDIUS My lord?
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text: Why did you so cry out, sirs, in your sleep?
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Did we, my lord?
BRUTUS Ay. Saw you anything?
VARRO No, my lord, I saw nothing. 350
175 Julius Caesar ACT 4. SC. 3
CLAUDIUS Nor I, my lord.
speaker: BOTH
scene_description: Brutus's tent - Ghosts and battle prep

text:
Go and commend me to my brother Cassius.
Bid him set on his powers betimes before,
And we will follow.
BOTH It shall be done, my lord. 355
They exit.
Enter Octavius, Antony, and their army.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text:
Now, Antony, our hopes are answerèd.
You said the enemy would not come down
But keep the hills and upper regions.
It proves not so; their battles are at hand.
They mean to warn us at Philippi here, 5
Answering before we do demand of them.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text:
Tut, I am in their bosoms, and I know
Wherefore they do it. They could be content
To visit other places, and come down
With fearful bravery, thinking by this face 10
To fasten in our thoughts that they have courage.
But ’tis not so.
Enter a Messenger.
MESSENGER Prepare you, generals.
The enemy comes on in gallant show.
Their bloody sign of battle is hung out, 15
And something to be done immediately.
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text:
Octavius, lead your battle softly on
Upon the left hand of the even field.
179
181 Julius Caesar ACT 5. SC. 1
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text: Upon the right hand, I; keep thou the left.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text: Why do you cross me in this exigent? 20
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text:
I do not cross you, but I will do so. March.
Drum. Enter Brutus, Cassius, and their army including
Lucilius, Titinius, and Messala.
BRUTUS They stand and would have parley.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text: Stand fast, Titinius. We must out and talk.
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text: Mark Antony, shall we give sign of battle?
speaker: OCTAVIUS
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text:
No, Caesar, we will answer on their charge. 25
Make forth. The Generals would have some words.
OCTAVIUS, to his Officers Stir not until the signal.
The Generals step forward.
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text: Words before blows; is it so, countrymen?
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text: Not that we love words better, as you do.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text: Good words are better than bad strokes, Octavius. 30
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text:
In your bad strokes, Brutus, you give good words.
Witness the hole you made in Caesar’s heart,
Crying “Long live, hail, Caesar!”
CASSIUS Antony,
The posture of your blows are yet unknown, 35
But, for your words, they rob the Hybla bees
And leave them honeyless.
ANTONY Not stingless too.
BRUTUS O yes, and soundless too,
183 Julius Caesar ACT 5. SC. 1
For you have stolen their buzzing, Antony, 40
And very wisely threat before you sting.
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text:
Villains, you did not so when your vile daggers
Hacked one another in the sides of Caesar.
You showed your teeth like apes and fawned like
hounds 45
And bowed like bondmen, kissing Caesar’s feet,
Whilst damnèd Casca, like a cur, behind
Struck Caesar on the neck. O you flatterers!
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text:
Flatterers?—Now, Brutus, thank yourself!
This tongue had not offended so today 50
If Cassius might have ruled.
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text:
Come, come, the cause. If arguing make us sweat,
The proof of it will turn to redder drops.
Look, I draw a sword against conspirators;
He draws.
When think you that the sword goes up again? 55
Never, till Caesar’s three and thirty wounds
Be well avenged, or till another Caesar
Have added slaughter to the sword of traitors.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text:
Caesar, thou canst not die by traitors’ hands
Unless thou bring’st them with thee. 60
OCTAVIUS So I hope.
I was not born to die on Brutus’ sword.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text:
O, if thou wert the noblest of thy strain,
Young man, thou couldst not die more honorable.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text:
A peevish schoolboy, worthless of such honor, 65
Joined with a masker and a reveler!
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text:
Old Cassius still.
OCTAVIUS Come, Antony, away!—
185 Julius Caesar ACT 5. SC. 1
Defiance, traitors, hurl we in your teeth.
If you dare fight today, come to the field; 70
If not, when you have stomachs.
Octavius, Antony, and their army exit.
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text:
Why now, blow wind, swell billow, and swim bark!
The storm is up, and all is on the hazard.
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text:
Ho, Lucilius, hark, a word with you.
Lucilius and Messala stand forth.
LUCILIUS My lord? 75
Brutus and Lucilius step aside together.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text:
Messala.
MESSALA What says my general?
CASSIUS Messala,
This is my birthday, as this very day
Was Cassius born. Give me thy hand, Messala. 80
Be thou my witness that against my will
(As Pompey was) am I compelled to set
Upon one battle all our liberties.
You know that I held Epicurus strong
And his opinion. Now I change my mind 85
And partly credit things that do presage.
Coming from Sardis, on our former ensign
Two mighty eagles fell, and there they perched,
Gorging and feeding from our soldiers’ hands,
Who to Philippi here consorted us. 90
This morning are they fled away and gone,
And in their steads do ravens, crows, and kites
Fly o’er our heads and downward look on us
As we were sickly prey. Their shadows seem
A canopy most fatal, under which 95
Our army lies, ready to give up the ghost.
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text:
Believe not so.
187 Julius Caesar ACT 5. SC. 1
CASSIUS I but believe it partly,
For I am fresh of spirit and resolved
To meet all perils very constantly. 100
speaker: MESSALA
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text:
Even so, Lucilius. Brutus returns to Cassius.
CASSIUS Now, most noble Brutus,
The gods today stand friendly that we may,
Lovers in peace, lead on our days to age.
But since the affairs of men rests still incertain, 105
Let’s reason with the worst that may befall.
If we do lose this battle, then is this
The very last time we shall speak together.
What are you then determinèd to do?
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text:
Even by the rule of that philosophy 110
By which I did blame Cato for the death
Which he did give himself (I know not how,
But I do find it cowardly and vile,
For fear of what might fall, so to prevent
The time of life), arming myself with patience 115
To stay the providence of some high powers
That govern us below.
CASSIUS Then, if we lose this battle,
You are contented to be led in triumph
Thorough the streets of Rome? 120
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text:
No, Cassius, no. Think not, thou noble Roman,
That ever Brutus will go bound to Rome.
He bears too great a mind. But this same day
Must end that work the ides of March begun.
And whether we shall meet again, I know not. 125
Therefore our everlasting farewell take.
Forever and forever farewell, Cassius.
If we do meet again, why we shall smile;
If not, why then this parting was well made.
189 Julius Caesar ACT 5. SC. 3
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Plains near Philippi - Armies prepare for battle

text:
Why then, lead on.—O, that a man might know
The end of this day’s business ere it come!
But it sufficeth that the day will end, 135
And then the end is known.—Come ho, away!
They exit.
Alarum. Enter Brutus and Messala.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: The battlefield - Fighting begins

text:
Ride, ride, Messala, ride, and give these bills
Unto the legions on the other side!
He hands Messala papers.
Loud alarum.
Let them set on at once, for I perceive
But cold demeanor in Octavius’ wing,
And sudden push gives them the overthrow. 5
Ride, ride, Messala! Let them all come down.
They exit.
Alarums. Enter Cassius carrying a standard and
Titinius.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Another part of the field - Casualties mount

text:
O, look, Titinius, look, the villains fly!
Myself have to mine own turned enemy.
This ensign here of mine was turning back;
I slew the coward and did take it from him.
191 Julius Caesar ACT 5. SC. 3
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Another part of the field - Casualties mount

text:
O Cassius, Brutus gave the word too early, 5
Who, having some advantage on Octavius,
Took it too eagerly. His soldiers fell to spoil,
Whilst we by Antony are all enclosed.
Enter Pindarus.
speaker: TITINIUS
scene_description: Another part of the field - Casualties mount

text:
Fly further off, my lord, fly further off!
Mark Antony is in your tents, my lord. 10
Fly therefore, noble Cassius, fly far off.
speaker: PINDARUS
scene_description: Another part of the field - Casualties mount

text:
This hill is far enough.—Look, look, Titinius,
Are those my tents where I perceive the fire?
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Another part of the field - Casualties mount

text:
They are, my lord.
CASSIUS Titinius, if thou lovest me, 15
Mount thou my horse and hide thy spurs in him
Till he have brought thee up to yonder troops
And here again, that I may rest assured
Whether yond troops are friend or enemy.
speaker: TITINIUS
scene_description: Another part of the field - Casualties mount

text: I will be here again even with a thought. He exits. 20
speaker: TITINIUS
scene_description: Another part of the field - Casualties mount

text:
Go, Pindarus, get higher on that hill.
My sight was ever thick. Regard Titinius
And tell me what thou not’st about the field.
Pindarus goes up.
This day I breathèd first. Time is come round,
And where I did begin, there shall I end; 25
My life is run his compass.—Sirrah, what news?
PINDARUS, above. O my lord!
CASSIUS What news?
speaker: CASSIUS
scene_description: Another part of the field - Casualties mount

text:
Titinius is enclosèd round about
193 Julius Caesar ACT 5. SC. 3
With horsemen that make to him on the spur, 30
Yet he spurs on. Now they are almost on him.
Now Titinius! Now some light. O, he lights too.
He’s ta’en. Shout.
And hark, they shout for joy.
CASSIUS Come down, behold no more.— 35
O, coward that I am to live so long
To see my best friend ta’en before my face!
Pindarus comes down.
Come hither, sirrah.
In Parthia did I take thee prisoner,
And then I swore thee, saving of thy life, 40
That whatsoever I did bid thee do
Thou shouldst attempt it. Come now, keep thine
oath.
Now be a freeman, and with this good sword,
That ran through Caesar’s bowels, search this 45
bosom.
Stand not to answer. Here, take thou the hilts,
And, when my face is covered, as ’tis now,
Guide thou the sword. Pindarus stabs him.
Caesar, thou art revenged 50
Even with the sword that killed thee. He dies.
speaker: PINDARUS
scene_description: Another part of the field - Casualties mount

text:
So I am free, yet would not so have been,
Durst I have done my will.—O Cassius!—
Far from this country Pindarus shall run,
Where never Roman shall take note of him. 55
He exits.
Enter Titinius and Messala.
speaker: PINDARUS
scene_description: Another part of the field - Casualties mount

text:
It is but change, Titinius, for Octavius
Is overthrown by noble Brutus’ power,
As Cassius’ legions are by Antony.
195 Julius Caesar ACT 5. SC. 3
speaker: MESSALA
scene_description: Another part of the field - Casualties mount

text: These tidings will well comfort Cassius.
speaker: TITINIUS
scene_description: Another part of the field - Casualties mount

text:
Where did you leave him? 60
TITINIUS All disconsolate,
With Pindarus his bondman, on this hill.
speaker: MESSALA
scene_description: Another part of the field - Casualties mount

text: Is not that he that lies upon the ground?
speaker: MESSALA
scene_description: Another part of the field - Casualties mount

text: He lies not like the living. O my heart!
speaker: TITINIUS
scene_description: Another part of the field - Casualties mount

text:
Is not that he? 65
TITINIUS No, this was he, Messala,
But Cassius is no more. O setting sun,
As in thy red rays thou dost sink to night,
So in his red blood Cassius’ day is set.
The sun of Rome is set. Our day is gone; 70
Clouds, dews, and dangers come. Our deeds are
done.
Mistrust of my success hath done this deed.
speaker: MESSALA
scene_description: Another part of the field - Casualties mount

text:
Mistrust of good success hath done this deed.
O hateful error, melancholy’s child, 75
Why dost thou show to the apt thoughts of men
The things that are not? O error, soon conceived,
Thou never com’st unto a happy birth
But kill’st the mother that engendered thee!
speaker: MESSALA
scene_description: Another part of the field - Casualties mount

text: What, Pindarus! Where art thou, Pindarus? 80
speaker: TITINIUS
scene_description: Another part of the field - Casualties mount

text:
Seek him, Titinius, whilst I go to meet
The noble Brutus, thrusting this report
Into his ears. I may say “thrusting it,”
For piercing steel and darts envenomèd
Shall be as welcome to the ears of Brutus 85
As tidings of this sight.
197 Julius Caesar ACT 5. SC. 3
TITINIUS Hie you, Messala,
And I will seek for Pindarus the while.
Messala exits.
Why didst thou send me forth, brave Cassius?
Did I not meet thy friends, and did not they 90
Put on my brows this wreath of victory
And bid me give it thee? Didst thou not hear their
shouts?
Alas, thou hast misconstrued everything.
But hold thee, take this garland on thy brow. 95
Laying the garland on Cassius’ brow.
Thy Brutus bid me give it thee, and I
Will do his bidding.—Brutus, come apace,
And see how I regarded Caius Cassius.—
By your leave, gods, this is a Roman’s part.
Come, Cassius’ sword, and find Titinius’ heart! 100
He dies on Cassius’ sword.
Alarum. Enter Brutus, Messala, young Cato, Strato,
Volumnius, and Lucilius, Labeo, and Flavius.
speaker: MESSALA
scene_description: Another part of the field - Casualties mount

text: Where, where, Messala, doth his body lie?
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Another part of the field - Casualties mount

text: Lo, yonder, and Titinius mourning it.
speaker: MESSALA
scene_description: Another part of the field - Casualties mount

text:
Titinius’ face is upward.
CATO He is slain.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Another part of the field - Casualties mount

text:
O Julius Caesar, thou art mighty yet; 105
Thy spirit walks abroad and turns our swords
In our own proper entrails. Low alarums.
CATO Brave Titinius!—
Look whe’er he have not crowned dead Cassius.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: Another part of the field - Casualties mount

text:
Are yet two Romans living such as these?— 110
The last of all the Romans, fare thee well.
199 Julius Caesar ACT 5. SC. 4
It is impossible that ever Rome
Should breed thy fellow.—Friends, I owe more
tears
To this dead man than you shall see me pay.— 115
I shall find time, Cassius; I shall find time.—
Come, therefore, and to Thasos send his body.
His funerals shall not be in our camp,
Lest it discomfort us.—Lucilius, come.—
And come, young Cato. Let us to the field.— 120
Labeo and Flavius, set our battles on.
’Tis three o’clock, and, Romans, yet ere night
We shall try fortune in a second fight.
They exit.
Alarum. Enter Brutus, Messala, Cato, Lucilius, and
Flavius.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: The battlefield - Brutus falls

text:
Yet, countrymen, O, yet hold up your heads!
Brutus, Messala, and Flavius exit.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: The battlefield - Brutus falls

text:
What bastard doth not? Who will go with me?
I will proclaim my name about the field.
I am the son of Marcus Cato, ho!
A foe to tyrants and my country’s friend. 5
I am the son of Marcus Cato, ho!
Enter Soldiers and fight.
speaker: CATO
scene_description: The battlefield - Brutus falls

text:
And I am Brutus, Marcus Brutus, I!
Brutus, my country’s friend! Know me for Brutus.
Cato is killed.
O young and noble Cato, art thou down?
201 Julius Caesar ACT 5. SC. 4
Why, now thou diest as bravely as Titinius 10
And mayst be honored, being Cato’s son.
FIRST SOLDIER, seizing Lucilius
Yield, or thou diest.
LUCILIUS Only I yield to die.
There is so much that thou wilt kill me straight.
Offering money.
Kill Brutus and be honored in his death. 15
speaker: LUCILIUS
scene_description: The battlefield - Brutus falls

text:
We must not. A noble prisoner!
Enter Antony.
speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
scene_description: The battlefield - Brutus falls

text: Room, ho! Tell Antony Brutus is ta’en.
speaker: SECOND SOLDIER
scene_description: The battlefield - Brutus falls

text:
I’ll tell the news. Here comes the General.—
Brutus is ta’en, Brutus is ta’en, my lord.
ANTONY Where is he? 20
speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
scene_description: The battlefield - Brutus falls

text:
Safe, Antony, Brutus is safe enough.
I dare assure thee that no enemy
Shall ever take alive the noble Brutus.
The gods defend him from so great a shame!
When you do find him, or alive or dead, 25
He will be found like Brutus, like himself.
speaker: LUCILIUS
scene_description: The battlefield - Brutus falls

text:
This is not Brutus, friend, but I assure you,
A prize no less in worth. Keep this man safe.
Give him all kindness. I had rather have
Such men my friends than enemies. Go on, 30
And see whe’er Brutus be alive or dead,
And bring us word unto Octavius’ tent
How everything is chanced.
They exit in different directions.
203 Julius Caesar ACT 5. SC. 5
Enter Brutus, Dardanus, Clitus, Strato, and Volumnius.
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text:
Come, poor remains of friends, rest on this rock.
He sits down.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text:
Statilius showed the torchlight, but, my lord,
He came not back. He is or ta’en or slain.
speaker: CLITUS
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text: What, I, my lord? No, not for all the world.
speaker: CLITUS
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text:
Peace, then, no words.
CLITUS I’ll rather kill myself.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text:
Hark thee, Dardanus. He whispers to Dardanus.
DARDANUS Shall I do such a deed? 10
CLITUS O Dardanus!
DARDANUS O Clitus!
Dardanus and Clitus step aside.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text: What ill request did Brutus make to thee?
speaker: CLITUS
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text: To kill him, Clitus. Look, he meditates.
speaker: DARDANUS
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text:
Now is that noble vessel full of grief, 15
That it runs over even at his eyes.
speaker: CLITUS
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text: Come hither, good Volumnius. List a word.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text:
What says my lord?
BRUTUS Why this, Volumnius:
205 Julius Caesar ACT 5. SC. 5
The ghost of Caesar hath appeared to me 20
Two several times by night—at Sardis once
And this last night here in Philippi fields.
I know my hour is come.
VOLUMNIUS Not so, my lord.
speaker: VOLUMNIUS
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text:
Nay, I am sure it is, Volumnius. 25
Thou seest the world, Volumnius, how it goes.
Our enemies have beat us to the pit. Low alarums.
It is more worthy to leap in ourselves
Than tarry till they push us. Good Volumnius,
Thou know’st that we two went to school together; 30
Even for that our love of old, I prithee,
Hold thou my sword hilts whilst I run on it.
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text:
That’s not an office for a friend, my lord.
Alarum continues.
speaker: VOLUMNIUS
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text: Fly, fly, my lord! There is no tarrying here.
speaker: CLITUS
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text:
Farewell to you—and you—and you, Volumnius.— 35
Strato, thou hast been all this while asleep.
Farewell to thee, too, Strato.—Countrymen,
My heart doth joy that yet in all my life
I found no man but he was true to me.
I shall have glory by this losing day 40
More than Octavius and Mark Antony
By this vile conquest shall attain unto.
So fare you well at once, for Brutus’ tongue
Hath almost ended his life’s history.
Night hangs upon mine eyes; my bones would rest, 45
That have but labored to attain this hour.
Alarum. Cry within “Fly, fly, fly!”
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text:
Fly, my lord, fly!
BRUTUS Hence. I will follow.
All exit but Brutus and Strato.
207 Julius Caesar ACT 5. SC. 5
I prithee, Strato, stay thou by thy lord.
Thou art a fellow of a good respect; 50
Thy life hath had some smatch of honor in it.
Hold, then, my sword, and turn away thy face
While I do run upon it. Wilt thou, Strato?
speaker: CLITUS
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text: Give me your hand first. Fare you well, my lord.
speaker: STRATO
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text:
Farewell, good Strato. 55
Brutus runs on his sword.
Caesar, now be still.
I killed not thee with half so good a will. He dies.
Alarum. Retreat. Enter Antony, Octavius, Messala,
Lucilius, and the army.
OCTAVIUS What man is that?
speaker: BRUTUS
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text: My master’s man.—Strato, where is thy master?
speaker: MESSALA
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text:
Free from the bondage you are in, Messala. 60
The conquerors can but make a fire of him,
For Brutus only overcame himself,
And no man else hath honor by his death.
speaker: STRATO
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text:
So Brutus should be found.—I thank thee, Brutus,
That thou hast proved Lucilius’ saying true. 65
speaker: LUCILIUS
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text:
All that served Brutus, I will entertain them.—
Fellow, wilt thou bestow thy time with me?
speaker: OCTAVIUS
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text: Ay, if Messala will prefer me to you.
speaker: STRATO
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text:
Do so, good Messala.
MESSALA How died my master, Strato? 70
speaker: OCTAVIUS
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text:
I held the sword, and he did run on it.
209 Julius Caesar ACT 5. SC. 5
speaker: STRATO
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text:
Octavius, then take him to follow thee,
That did the latest service to my master.
speaker: MESSALA
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text:
This was the noblest Roman of them all.
All the conspirators save only he 75
Did that they did in envy of great Caesar.
He only in a general honest thought
And common good to all made one of them.
His life was gentle and the elements
So mixed in him that nature might stand up 80
And say to all the world “This was a man.”
speaker: ANTONY
scene_description: The battlefield - Aftermath and conclusion

text:
According to his virtue, let us use him
With all respect and rites of burial.
Within my tent his bones tonight shall lie,
Most like a soldier, ordered honorably. 85
So call the field to rest, and let’s away
To part the glories of this happy day.
They all exit.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
